summary: Project LIFEAT was a CIA unilateral telephone tap operation conducted in Mexico City. It primarily targeted Soviet, Satellite, and Cuban agents, as well as official foreign installations. The operation involved intercepting telephone communications from these targets, processing and exploiting the intelligence gathered, and managing personnel involved in the operation. LIFEAT was active from at least January 1962 through June 1963, with a budget of $99,000 allocated for the period of July 1962 to June 1963. The operation involved phone tapping, technical support, security measures, and personnel recruitment. Documents related to LIFEAT include cables, memorandums, and dispatches concerning personnel, transportation allowances, and operational details. The operation was supported by KDMANGO and involved sources such as LIENVOY-8. The Mexico City Station was responsible for carrying out the operation, facing administrative challenges and personnel issues while striving for efficiency in agent recruitment and inter-station support.
significance: While the provided documents do not explicitly link LIFEAT to the JFK assassination, its focus on monitoring Soviet, Cuban, and satellite communications in Mexico City during the period leading up to the assassination makes it potentially relevant. Lee Harvey Oswald visited Mexico City a few weeks before the assassination, and any intelligence gathered by LIFEAT on individuals or groups he may have contacted could be of interest. The documents suggest the operation was ongoing and actively collecting intelligence during a critical period.
